common_questions.what is malaria: Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by parasites transmitted to people through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes.
common_questions.what are symptoms of malaria: Symptoms of malaria include fever, chills, headache, nausea, and vomiting, often appearing 10-15 days after the infective mosquito bite.
common_questions.how is malaria treated: Malaria is treated with antimalarial medications such as chloroquine, artemisinin, or combination therapies.
common_questions.how is malaria diagnosed: Malaria is diagnosed by a blood test that looks for parasites.
common_questions.how to prevent malaria: Prevent malaria by using mosquito nets, applying insect repellent, and taking antimalarial medications.
common_questions.what is hiv and aids: HIV is a virus that attacks the bodyâ€™s immune system, potentially leading to AIDS if not treated.
common_questions.what are symptoms of hiv and aids: Early symptoms include fever, sore throat, and fatigue. Later symptoms can include weight loss, night sweats, and frequent infections.
common_questions.how is hiv and aids treated: HIV/AIDS is treated using antiretroviral therapy (ART) to help control the virus and prevent progression to AIDS.
common_questions.how is hiv and aids transmitted: HIV is spread through contact with certain body fluids such as blood, semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk.
common_questions.how to prevent hiv and aids: Prevent HIV/AIDS by practicing safe sex, using clean needles, and taking preventive medications like PrEP.
common_questions.what is tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
common_questions.what are symptoms of tuberculosis: Symptoms of TB include a persistent cough, chest pain, weight loss, and night sweats.
common_questions.how is tuberculosis treated: Tuberculosis is treated with antibiotics over a period of several months.
common_questions.how is tuberculosis diagnosed: TB is diagnosed through skin tests, blood tests, and chest X-rays.
common_questions.how to prevent tuberculosis: Prevent TB by getting vaccinated and maintaining good hygiene.
common_questions.what is influenza: Influenza (flu) is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses.
common_questions.what are symptoms of influenza: Symptoms include fever, chills, muscle aches, cough, congestion, runny nose, headaches, and fatigue.
common_questions.how is influenza treated: Treatment includes rest, fluids, and, in some cases, antiviral medications.
common_questions.how is influenza diagnosed: Flu is diagnosed through physical exams and sometimes rapid influenza diagnostic tests.
common_questions.how to prevent influenza: Prevent flu by getting vaccinated annually and practicing good hand hygiene.
common_questions.what is diabetes: Diabetes is a chronic health condition that affects how your body turns food into energy due to issues with insulin.
common_questions.what are symptoms of diabetes: Symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, hunger, fatigue, and blurred vision.
common_questions.how is diabetes treated: Treatment includes lifestyle changes, monitoring blood sugar, insulin therapy, and medications.
common_questions.how is diabetes diagnosed: Diabetes is diagnosed through blood tests that measure blood sugar levels.
common_questions.how to prevent diabetes: Prevent diabetes by maintaining a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and a balanced diet.
common_questions.what is cancer: Cancer is a disease in which abnormal cells divide uncontrollably and destroy body tissue.
common_questions.what are symptoms of cancer: Symptoms vary but can include lumps, abnormal bleeding, prolonged cough, and unexplained weight loss.
common_questions.how is cancer treated: Treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy.
common_questions.how is cancer diagnosed: Cancer is diagnosed through imaging tests, biopsy, and lab tests.
common_questions.how to prevent cancer: Prevent cancer by avoiding tobacco, maintaining a healthy diet, and getting regular screenings.
common_questions.what is covid-19: COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
common_questions.what are symptoms of covid-19: Symptoms include fever, cough, shortness of breath, loss of taste or smell, and fatigue.
common_questions.how is covid-19 treated: Treatment includes rest, hydration, and, in severe cases, hospitalization and oxygen therapy.
common_questions.how is covid-19 diagnosed: COVID-19 is diagnosed using PCR tests, antigen tests, and sometimes antibody tests.
common_questions.how to prevent covid-19: Prevent COVID-19 by wearing masks, maintaining physical distance, and getting vaccinated.
common_questions.what is cholera: Cholera is an acute diarrheal illness caused by infection of the intestine with Vibrio cholerae bacteria.
common_questions.what are symptoms of cholera: Symptoms include watery diarrhea, dehydration, and in severe cases, death if untreated.
common_questions.how is cholera treated: Treatment includes rehydration, antibiotics, and zinc supplements.
common_questions.how is cholera diagnosed: Cholera is diagnosed through stool samples.
common_questions.how to prevent cholera: Prevent cholera by drinking clean water, using toilets, and washing hands with soap.
common_questions.what is hepatitis: Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver, often caused by a viral infection.
common_questions.what are symptoms of hepatitis: Symptoms include fatigue, nausea, jaundice, and abdominal pain.
common_questions.how is hepatitis treated: Treatment varies by type but may include antiviral medications and lifestyle changes.
common_questions.how is hepatitis diagnosed: Hepatitis is diagnosed through blood tests and liver function tests.
common_questions.how to prevent hepatitis: Prevent hepatitis by getting vaccinated, avoiding contaminated food and water, and practicing safe sex.
common_questions.what is typhoid fever: Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, commonly spread through contaminated food and water.
common_questions.what are symptoms of typhoid fever: Symptoms include high fever, weakness, stomach pain, headache, and loss of appetite.
common_questions.how is typhoid fever treated: Typhoid is treated with antibiotics and supportive care, like hydration and rest.
common_questions.how is typhoid fever diagnosed: Typhoid is diagnosed with a blood or stool test to detect the presence of Salmonella typhi.
common_questions.how to prevent typhoid fever: Prevent typhoid by drinking safe water, eating properly cooked food, and getting vaccinated if at risk.
common_questions.what is mumps: Mumps is a viral infection primarily affecting the salivary glands, causing swelling and pain near the jawline.
common_questions.what are symptoms of mumps: Symptoms include swollen and painful salivary glands, fever, headache, and fatigue.
common_questions.how is mumps treated: There is no specific treatment for mumps; care focuses on symptom relief and isolation to prevent spread.
common_questions.how is mumps diagnosed: Mumps is diagnosed based on symptoms and confirmed with a blood test or saliva test.
common_questions.how to prevent mumps: Prevent mumps by getting vaccinated with the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine.
common_questions.what is chikungunya: Chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, causing fever and severe joint pain.
common_questions.what are symptoms of chikungunya: Symptoms include sudden fever, joint pain, headache, muscle pain, and rash.
common_questions.how is chikungunya treated: Treatment involves symptom relief, as there is no specific antiviral for chikungunya.
common_questions.how is chikungunya diagnosed: Chikungunya is diagnosed through blood tests that detect the virus or antibodies.
common_questions.how to prevent chikungunya: Prevent chikungunya by avoiding mosquito bites and using insect repellents.
common_questions.what is legionnaires disease: Legionnaires' disease is a severe form of pneumonia caused by Legionella bacteria, typically found in contaminated water systems.
common_questions.what are symptoms of legionnaires diseas: Symptoms include cough, shortness of breath, high fever, muscle aches, and headaches.
common_questions.how is legionnaires disease treated: Legionnaires' disease is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin or ciprofloxacin.
common_questions.how is legionnaires disease diagnosed: It is diagnosed through urine tests and lung samples that detect Legionella bacteria.
common_questions.how to prevent legionnaires disease: Prevent Legionnaires' by maintaining clean water systems in large buildings and avoiding inhaling mist from contaminated water sources.
common_questions.what is dengue fever: Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection causing flu-like symptoms and, in severe cases, hemorrhagic fever.
common_questions.what are symptoms of dengue fever: Symptoms include high fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint pain, rash, and mild bleeding.
common_questions.how is dengue fever treated: There is no specific treatment for dengue; symptoms are managed with fluids and pain relievers.
common_questions.how is dengue fever diagnosed: Dengue fever is diagnosed with blood tests that detect the virus or antibodies.
common_questions.how to prevent dengue fever: Prevent dengue by avoiding mosquito bites, using repellents, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed.
common_questions.what is shigellosis: Shigellosis is an infectious disease caused by a group of bacteria called Shigella, primarily causing diarrhea.
common_questions.what are symptoms of shigellosis: Symptoms include diarrhea (often bloody), fever, stomach cramps, and nausea.
common_questions.how is shigellosis treated: Shigellosis is often treated with antibiotics, but mild cases may recover without treatment.
common_questions.how is shigellosis diagnosed: Shigellosis is diagnosed by testing a stool sample for Shigella bacteria.
common_questions.how to prevent shigellosis: Prevent shigellosis by practicing good hygiene, especially handwashing, and avoiding contaminated food and water.
common_questions.what is rotavirus: Rotavirus is a highly contagious virus that causes severe diarrhea, mostly in infants and young children.
common_questions.what are symptoms of rotavirus: Symptoms include severe diarrhea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain.
common_questions.how is rotavirus treated: Treatment focuses on preventing dehydration through rehydration solutions, as there is no specific antiviral.
common_questions.how is rotavirus diagnosed: Rotavirus is diagnosed through a stool sample test.
common_questions.how to prevent rotavirus: Prevent rotavirus by getting vaccinated and practicing good hygiene.
common_questions.what is tetanus: Tetanus is a serious bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani, often through cuts or wounds.
common_questions.what are symptoms of tetanus: Symptoms include muscle stiffness, spasms, difficulty swallowing, and lockjaw.
common_questions.how is tetanus treated: Tetanus is treated with antitoxin, antibiotics, and muscle relaxants.
common_questions.how is tetanus diagnosed: Tetanus is diagnosed based on clinical symptoms and exposure history.
common_questions.how to prevent tetanus: Prevent tetanus by keeping up-to-date with vaccinations, especially after injury.
common_questions.what is zika virus: Zika virus is a mosquito-borne virus primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, often found in tropical and subtropical regions.
common_questions.what are symptoms of zika virus: Symptoms of Zika virus include fever, rash, joint pain, and red eyes, usually mild and lasting for several days.
common_questions.how is zika virus treated: There is no specific treatment for Zika; symptoms are managed with rest, fluids, and pain relievers.
common_questions.how is zika virus diagnosed: Zika virus is diagnosed through blood or urine tests.
common_questions.how to prevent zika virus: Prevent Zika by avoiding mosquito bites, using insect repellent, and wearing long-sleeved clothing.
common_questions.what is ebola: Ebola is a rare and deadly viral infection that causes severe bleeding, organ failure, and can be fatal.
common_questions.what are symptoms of ebola: Symptoms include fever, headache, muscle pain, and fatigue, progressing to vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding.
common_questions.how is ebola treated: Ebola is treated with supportive care and, in some cases, experimental antiviral drugs.
common_questions.how is ebola diagnosed: Ebola is diagnosed through blood tests that detect the virus.
common_questions.how to prevent ebola: Prevent Ebola by avoiding contact with infected individuals and practicing good hygiene.
common_questions.what is meningitis: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord, caused by infections.
common_questions.what are symptoms of meningitis: Symptoms include sudden high fever, headache, neck stiffness, and sensitivity to light.
common_questions.how is meningitis treated: Treatment depends on the cause but may include antibiotics or antiviral medications.
common_questions.how is meningitis diagnosed: Meningitis is diagnosed through a lumbar puncture to analyze spinal fluid.
common_questions.how to prevent meningitis: Prevent meningitis by getting vaccinated, especially for bacterial meningitis.
common_questions.what is hepatitis b: Hepatitis B is a viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic disease.
common_questions.what are symptoms of hepatitis b: Symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, dark urine, and abdominal pain.
common_questions.how is hepatitis b treated: Treatment includes antiviral medications for chronic cases and lifestyle changes to protect the liver.
common_questions.how is hepatitis b diagnosed: Hepatitis B is diagnosed through blood tests.
common_questions.how to prevent hepatitis b: Prevent hepatitis B by getting vaccinated and avoiding blood-borne and sexual exposure.
common_questions.what is rabies: Rabies is a viral disease that affects the central nervous system, typically spread through the bite of an infected animal.
common_questions.what are symptoms of rabies: Early symptoms include fever and tingling at the bite site, progressing to violent movements, and fear of water.
common_questions.how is rabies treated: Rabies is preventable with post-exposure prophylaxis but is almost always fatal once symptoms appear.
common_questions.how is rabies diagnosed: Rabies is diagnosed by testing samples of saliva, blood, skin, and cerebrospinal fluid.
common_questions.how to prevent rabies: Prevent rabies by vaccinating pets and avoiding contact with wild animals.
common_questions.what is measles: Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that causes fever, cough, runny nose, and a characteristic red rash.
common_questions.what are symptoms of measles: Symptoms include fever, cough, red eyes, and a rash that usually starts on the face and spreads.
common_questions.how is measles treated: There is no specific treatment; supportive care includes rest, hydration, and fever management.
common_questions.how is measles diagnosed: Measles is diagnosed through a clinical examination and confirmed with blood tests.
common_questions.how to prevent measles: Prevent measles by getting vaccinated with the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine.
common_questions.what is chickenpox: Chickenpox is a contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus, resulting in a blister-like rash.
common_questions.what are symptoms of chickenpox: Symptoms include itchy, blister-like rashes, fever, and fatigue.
common_questions.how is chickenpox treated: Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms with antihistamines and sometimes antiviral medications.
common_questions.how is chickenpox diagnosed: Chickenpox is diagnosed through a visual exam of the characteristic rash.
common_questions.how to prevent chickenpox: Prevent chickenpox by getting vaccinated with the varicella vaccine.
common_questions.what is lyme disease: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks.
common_questions.what are symptoms of lyme disease: Early symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic bull's-eye rash.
common_questions.how is lyme disease treated: Lyme disease is treated with antibiotics, usually doxycycline or amoxicillin.
common_questions.how is lyme disease diagnosed: Lyme disease is diagnosed through symptoms and confirmed with blood tests.
common_questions.how to prevent lyme disease: Prevent Lyme disease by avoiding tick bites, using repellent, and wearing protective clothing.
common_questions.what is polio: Polio is a viral disease that can cause paralysis and is transmitted through contaminated water and food.
common_questions.what are symptoms of polio: Symptoms include fever, fatigue, headache, vomiting, and, in severe cases, paralysis.
common_questions.how is polio treated: There is no cure for polio, but physical therapy can help manage symptoms.
common_questions.how is polio diagnosed: Polio is diagnosed through stool samples or throat swabs that detect the virus.
common_questions.how to prevent polio: Prevent polio by getting vaccinated with the polio vaccine.
common_questions.what is hantavirus: Hantavirus is a group of viruses spread mainly by rodents and can cause severe respiratory disease.
common_questions.what are symptoms of hantavirus: Early symptoms include fatigue, fever, and muscle aches, progressing to coughing and shortness of breath.
common_questions.how is hantavirus treated: There is no specific treatment, and care is supportive, focusing on managing respiratory symptoms.
common_questions.how is hantavirus diagnosed: Hantavirus is diagnosed with blood tests that identify the virus or its antibodies.
common_questions.how to prevent hantavirus: Prevent hantavirus by avoiding exposure to rodent droppings and nests.
